Ron,

I was not aware there was a Norisuke book. Want to
consider trading for the Namban tsuba book?

Seriously, if you find anything similar, please send
me a copy of the picture.

Curran


--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Curran - 
> 
> Finally got around to looking at your tsuba's photo
> and I can see why -- the flowers -- you think
> Norisuke. I have a book entirely on Norisuke which
> I'll take a look at, soon. I'm in the middle of
> photographing stuff in prep for our stein club
> meeting which I'm hosting this weekend. )Yes, too
> many "interests!") Anyway, I'll have a look in the
> book. No english but photos are pretty good. Once
> owned a mumei tsuba which was probably Norisuke
> work; Alan Harvie ended up with it. 
> 
> Ron
>   ----- Original Message ----- 
>   From: Curran Campbell 
>   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
>   Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:58 AM
>   Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari
> Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke
> 
> 
>   Alan,
> 
>   The tsuba is very thick and rich shakudo. It is
> very
>   heavy. The gold wire used is also very heavy
> guage,
>   set extremely deep into channels. It has retained
>   about 99.9% of the inlay, but there is a small
> spot on
>   the mimi where I can see how deep the channels run
> and
>   the gold wire extends all the way into it.
> 
>   According to Haynes and one or two other sources,
> the
>   Norisuke line did work in Kinko sometimes.
> 
>   I am not saying with 100% certainty that this is a
>   Norisuke, but there is a similar tsuba out there
> by
>   Norisuke and the more that I look at other tsuba
> by
>   the Norisuke family, the more I see the same
> design
>   elements over and over again. Leaf shape. Flower
> petal
>   engraving. Flower engraving. General composition.
> Very
>   much like a painting, the great number of details
>   evident in a soft metal heavily carved piece like
> this
>   seem to me a signature. There is some variation,
> like
>   there is a very similar 1st gen Norisuke example
> with
>   near identical leaves, but the main vein of the
> leaf
>   is done in a single track of gold vs the double
> vein I
>   have on this leaf.
>   I like to figure things out before I submit them
> to
>   shinsa, and sometimes if I am happy enough with an
>   answer and intend to keep a piece- I don't submit
> to
>   shinsa. I'd be surprised if I actually got a
>   'Norisuke' call on this, but as a
> newbie-intermediate
>   having something like this seem to click into
> place
>   has been very satisfying. Yet I may be absolutely
>   wrong! So if I can stand on someone's shoulder and
> see
>   further into this.... I welcome the view.
> 
>   If you want to take a crack at the other tsuba
> that
>   has been a challenge for me, I will dig that photo
> out
>   too and post it. This 'Norisuke' has been the more
>   interesting piece and horribly difficult to
> photograph
>   given the highly reflective shakudo and gold.
>   Photography is not a strong skill for me, yet the
>   devil of a good identification is also in the
> detail
>   of the other one.
> 
>   Curran
> 
>   --- Alan Bale <abale@...> wrote:
> 
>   > Is the tsuba iron or shakudo? I don't recall
> ever
>   > seeing a soft metal tsuba by Norisuke.
>   > Alan
>   > 
>   > ----- Original Message ----- 
>   > From: Curran Campbell 
>   > To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
>   > Sent: Monday, July 10, 2006 6:37 AM
>   > Subject: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko
>   > Tsuba and Norisuke
>   > 
>   > 
>   > List,
>   > 
>   > Regarding this tsuba: (Mystery Tsuba in Curran
>   > Folder)
>   > 
>   > http://tinyurl.com/lc3j2
>   > 
>   > Following up on the helpful lead provided by
> Alan
>   > Bale, I was able to borrow a copy of "Owari to
>   > Mikawa
>   > no Tanko" aka. Big Blue Owari Den tsuba book.
>   > 
>   > Reading through it as much as possible and
>   > consulting
>   > other texts, I feel the tsuba is an unsigned
> Owari
>   > kinko tsuba by Norisuke or someone close.
>   > 
>   > Anyone familiar with the Norisuke kinko work
> able
>   > to
>   > comment? Anyone able to tell me more about
>   > Norisuke
>   > kinko work?
>   > 
>   > I'd appreciate any insight or feedback.
>   > 
>   > Curran
>   > 
>   >
